title.narrative: Rhinoceros & Tiger Conservation-Species Conservation Grant

description.narrative: The supplementation of monitoring and security equipment to assist Namibia in protecting key Black and White Rhino populations against the onslaught of poaching

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: In partnership with the Namibian Ministry of Environment and Tourism, WWF and Google, we will co-fund the installation and operation of multiple new technology tools for protected area security. Tools will include remote cameras to monitor wildlife and to detect illegal trespass by people into the park and new communications systems.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This grant will support capacity building and specialized training of the Namibian organization that coordinates field patrolling and monitoring of desert black rhino (Diceros bicornis bicornis) in community areas. Specific activities include training courses for senior staff and operating costs necessary for ground patrols, aerial surveillance, and regular monitoring of individual rhinos in order to estimate population distribution and size and better focus security efforts.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Informant and crime management training course for rhino program field managers and investigators in Namibia

description.narrative: To assist Namibia in strengthening their ability to investigate and prosecute wildlife crime, this grant will support a ten-day training course conducted by experienced wildlife crime investigators for 24 participants from a range of rhino areas in Namibia, and to further refine the training course based on emerging issues and participant feedback for use in other African range states.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Equipping the Namibian national rhino program with a new wildlife veterinarian field vehicle

description.narrative: In order to respond to more efficiently and rapidly provide emergency veterinary care for black and white rhinos in northern Namibia, the country's wildlife authority will be posting a veterinary team in Etosha National Park. This grant will support the purchase and customization of a four-wheel drive vehicle for the veterinary team, equipped with all the necessary equipment for rhino capture for ear-notching, dehorning, implant of tracking devices, DNA sampling, capture and translocation of rhinos out of risky areas, and emergency veterinary care for injured rhinos.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: A proactive approach to combatting black rhino poaching in the Kunene and Erongo community areas of Namibia

description.narrative: To ensure the long-term security of the desert-adapted black rhino of the Kunene and Erongo Regions and prevent poaching and other illegal activities, these funds will be used to provide the training and operational expenses necessary to conduct anti-poaching patrols and rhino monitoring, to conduct aerial surveillance, and to liaise with law enforcement officials if suspicious activities or threats to rhinos are encountered, and to conduct scene-of-the-crime investigations.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Dehorning Namibia's rhinos to stem the rising tide of rhino poaching

description.narrative: In response to the increasing threat of poaching for rhino horn, Namibia has adopted a pro-active strategy of dehorning all rhinos. This grant will support an outreach and publicity campaign to make it known locally and internationally that Namibias rhinos do not have valuable horns, rhino immobilization operations to conduct dehorning and veterinary monitoring, implantation of tracking devices in all rhinos and all removed horns, ear-notching unmarked rhinos to facilitate identification and monitoring from a distance, collecting DNA samples of all rhinos and the horns, safe transport of horns from field sites to the secure national stockpile.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Determining the size and demographics of the Key 1 black rhino population of Etosha National Park

description.narrative: In order to secure and manage Namibias largest rhino population, Namibias Ministry of Environment and Tourism will conduct an aerial block count of Etosha National Park in 2016, using fixed wing aircraft and helicopters, in order to improve the accuracy of their population census, to map and sample any carcasses (poached or natural mortality), and to age and sex all observed rhinos.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Dehorning black rhinos in Namibias Custodian Program to deter poaching

description.narrative: In response to the increasing threat of poaching for rhino horn, Namibia has adopted a pro-active strategy of dehorning all rhinos. This grant will support an outreach and publicity campaign to make it known locally and internationally that Namibias rhinos do not have valuable horns, rhino immobilization operations to conduct dehorning and veterinary monitoring in community and conservancy areas, implantation of tracking devices in all rhinos and all removed horns, ear-notching unmarked rhinos to facilitate identification and monitoring from a distance, collecting DNA samples of all rhinos and the horns, and securing removed horns.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Protecting and monitoring the Kunene and Erongo Regions Key 1 population of black rhino

description.narrative: To ensure the long-term security of the desert-adapted black rhino of the Kunene and Erongo Regions of Namibia, and to prevent poaching and other illegal activities, these funds will be used to provide the training and operational expenses necessary to conduct anti-poaching patrols and rhino monitoring, to conduct aerial surveillance, and to liaise with law enforcement officials if suspicious activities or threats to rhinos are encountered, and to conduct scene-of-the-crime investigations.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Dehorning and translocating rhino throughout Namibia for biological management and security reasons

description.narrative: In response to the increased threat of poaching, Namibia has decided to minimize the risk of poaching by removing horns from rhinos in vulnerable areas, and by translocating rhinos out of the highest risk areas. Funds will be used to support dehorning and translocation operations. Specific activities include: darting, immobilizing and dehorning live rhinos in situ, installing security devices in all horns and submitting horn samples for DNA fingerprinting for forensic purposes, and darting, capturing and relocating rhinos when necessary.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Countering Wildlife Trafficking through Transcontinental Collaboration Across the African-Asian Nexus

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to address the Africa-Asia wildlife trafficking nexus, a direct threat causing loss of species in Africa. While the majority of illegal shipments from Africa are headed for China, smugglers use several transit countries to avoid detection. Cambodia is recognized by CITES as an important transit hub for high value wildlife products from Africa to China. To counter this problem, Wildlife Alliance has conducted a series of counter-wildlife trafficking trainings for Cambodian Customs at international ports. Although significant improvements continue to be made in the wildlife law enforcement practices of Cambodian Customs, a significant gap remains: lack of post-seizure investigations and arrests. Specific activities will include: (1) reaching to the countries of origin (Namibia, Kenya, Uganda, Angola, Mozambique, South Africa) and (2) to neighboring country Vietnam, which is a key link in investigations because Ho Chi Min Customs have recently intercepted shipments from Africa destined for Cambodia; in addition, several Cambodian ivory importing companies are owned by Vietnamese nationals.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Countering Wildlife Trafficking through Transcontinental Collaboration Across the African-Asian Nexus

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to address the Africa-Asia wildlife trafficking nexus, a direct threat causing loss of species in Africa. While the majority of illegal shipments from Africa are headed for China, smugglers use several transit countries to avoid detection. Cambodia is recognized by CITES as an important transit hub for high value wildlife products from Africa to China. To counter this problem, Wildlife Alliance has conducted a series of counter-wildlife trafficking trainings for Cambodian Customs at international ports. Although significant improvements continue to be made in the wildlife law enforcement practices of Cambodian Customs, a significant gap remains: lack of post-seizure investigations and arrests. Specific activities will include: (1) reaching to the countries of origin (Namibia, Kenya, Uganda, Angola, Mozambique, South Africa) and (2) to neighboring country Vietnam, which is a key link in investigations because Ho Chi Min Customs have recently intercepted shipments from Africa destined for Cambodia; in addition, several Cambodian ivory importing companies are owned by Vietnamese nationals.

title.narrative: Maintaining high standards of monitoring and protection of the Kunene Regions Key 1 black rhino population

description.narrative: To ensure the long-term security of the desert-adapted black rhino of the Kunene and Erongo Regions of Namibia, and to prevent poaching and other illegal activities, these funds will be used to provide the training and operational expenses necessary to conduct anti-poaching patrols and monitoring of the free ranging rhinos, to liaise with law enforcement officials if suspicious activities, illegal incursions by people or livestock into protected areas, or threats to rhinos are encountered, to secure crime scenes, and to work with the police, prosecutors and judiciary to collect and present evidence in rhino-related court cases.

title.narrative: Developing canine unit capacity in Etosha National Park, Namibia, to support law enforcement efforts and reduce rhino poaching

description.narrative: This project will establish a canine unit trained for detection of target substances and for tracking for Etosha NP. Activities will include the construction of kennels at the Wildlife Protection Service School in Waterberg NP and in Etosha NP, the purchase and training of four dogs, training of eight handlers, and operational expenses for deployment of the dog teams.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Developing canine unit capacity in Etosha National Park, Namibia, to support law enforcement efforts and reduce rhino poaching

description.narrative: This project will establish a canine unit trained for detection of target substances and for tracking for Etosha NP. Activities will include the construction of kennels at the Wildlife Protection Service School in Waterberg NP and in Etosha NP, the purchase and training of four dogs, training of eight handlers, and operational expenses for deployment of the dog teams.

title.narrative: Using satellite and RFID-tag bracelets in two Namibian national parks to assist black rhino monitoring and law enforcement efforts

description.narrative: The grantee aims to reduce rhino poaching in Etosha and Mangetti National Parks by increasing rhino monitoring and improving anti-poaching efforts. Specific activities will include implanting tracking devices on black rhinos in order to monitor their movements in high-density and high-risk areas in Etosha and Mangetti national parks, and using predictive modelling based on the data collected in order to determine movement patterns and deploy anti-poaching patrols accordingly.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Facilitating the 13th IUCN SSC African Rhino Specialist Group meeting, to be held in February 2019, Namibia

description.narrative: This grant will provide support for a continent-wide meeting to assess the state of all Africa's rhino species and subspecies, to assess the viability of the remaining populations, and to identify actions urgently needed to combat poaching. This meeting will only be the 13th such global meeting of experts since 1979. Technical experts (including site managers, veterinarians and national rhino coordinators) and official representatives of each range country will attend in order to compile the information required by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) for the 2019 Conference of the Parties, and to provide unified, objective impartial advice on emerging issues affecting Africas rhinos.

title.narrative: Expanding canine unit capacity in Namibia to support law enforcement efforts and reduce rhino poaching

description.narrative: to expand a law enforcement effort in Namibia to protect its populations of black rhinos, for which poaching is the most immediate threat. Since the launching of Namibias first canine unit in 2018, the dogs have had a significant impact on tackling poaching. Efforts will expand the canine unit program by adding an additional team in the Kunene Region and in Mangetti National Park, although the dogs will be deployed nationally as required.

title.narrative: PROTECTING AND MANAGING NAMIBIA S KEY 1 AND KEY 2 BLACK RHINO POPULATIONS FOR MAXIMUM GROWTH

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT BY FACILITATING OPERATIONS TO PROTECTCRITICALLY ENDANGERED BLACK RHINOCEROS IN NAMIBIA, THE STRONGHOLD FOR THE SOUTHWESTERN SUBSPECIES. THISPROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BLACK RHINOCEROS AND THEIR HABITAT IN NAMIBIA BYADDRESSING THE ONGOING POACHING CRISIS AND THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THISPROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THE MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT, FORESTRY AND TOURISM IN NAMIBIA, SAVE THERHINO TRUST AND THE BLACK RHINO CUSTODIANSHIP PROGRAM FOR: (1) MANAGING THE BLACK RHINOCEROSMETAPOPULATION TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINED AND POSITIVE POPULATION GROWTH (2) IMPROVING RHINOCEROS PROTECTION (3) EXPANDING COORDINATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS (4) UNDERSTANDING THEIMPACTS OF BIOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT AND SECURITY FOR RHINOCEROS POPULATIONS, AND (5) IMPROVING LIVINGCONDITIONS FOR STAFF AND PROVIDING NEEDED FIELD EQUIPMENT AND RESOURCES FOR THE PROTECTION OF BLACKRHINOCEROS.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: PROTECTING AND MANAGING NAMIBIA S KEY 1 AND KEY 2 BLACK RHINO POPULATIONS FOR MAXIMUM GROWTH

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort by facilitating operations to protect critically endangered black rhinoceros in Namibia, the stronghold for the Southwestern subspecies. This project is intended to conserve critically endangered black rhinoceros and their habitat in Namibia by addressing the ongoing poaching crisis and the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. This project will provide support to the Ministry of Environment, Forestry and Tourism in Namibia, Save the Rhino Trust and the Black Rhino Custodianship Program for: (1) managing the black rhinoceros metapopulation to achieve sustained and positive population growth; (2) improving rhinoceros protection; (3) expanding coordination among stakeholders including private landowners; (4) understanding the impacts of biological management and security for rhinoceros populations, and (5) improving living conditions for staff and providing needed field equipment and resources for the protection of black rhinoceros
